ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It was like a reading seminar. It was interesting to talk about a variety of different topics but we didn't cover any in too much depth. We had some great discussions.
Strengths: well structured, catered to student interest, discussion based Weaknesses: Discussion was sometimes around the same points, just focused on a different scenario.
Maybe have more of a mix-up of assignments- weekly write-ups become predictable.. discussions were really good though!

Great topic, but I thought it was odd that we finished an hour early every week, and that the sole focus of the class appeared to be critiquing one article each week. I would have preferred the instructor to give more lectures, especially given her strong background in/vast knowledge of perinatal epidemiology. I would have also liked for student-led introductions to the topic to take place the week before the article was due, so that we had some background information before reading the article.

This class helped me become better at reading and evaluating epidemiology papers, but I believe there is still room for improvement in this regard. We spent most classtime just discussing the topics relevant to the paper each week, but I think the experience could have been improved by allocating some time each week to discuss and reinforce general epidemiology topics (e.g., misclassification, publication bias, quality of prenatal data) as they relate to the study of prenatal health.
Heavily discussion based, it is an ideal course for anyone interested in discussing various topics related to perinatal health.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Great! Very understanding. Helped facilitate great discussions.
Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Adrienne was very attentive to student needs and really enjoyable to be around. She knew the literature very well and was responsive to students.
Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Very knowledgeable, but I would have liked her to give more lectures (not have the article critique be the main focus of every class).

Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Always willing to provide additional information on any subject matter that interests you, she was an ideal instructor for someone looking for more information on perinatal topics. She's also got a great sense of humor and is very approachable.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I really enjoyed it. I think it is great if you are interested in a career working with newborns/pregnant women. It can give you a general idea of a lot of the issues related to perinatal health.
I would recommend it, I liked the material and you got out of it what you put in.
i would recommend if the student has interest in this topic!

For those who want an opportunity to explore more of their subject of interest in perinatal health, while also being exposed to the whole host of issues concerning publications, methods, etc. on the topic.
